qwick745 01/04/2021 8:05 PM
How about something similar to the way a hotspot transfer is now setup, where one party offers the sale to the second party and the transfer happens once the second party accepts - for any owner to be able to submit a change of location and it would then be sent as a request to the other owner to agree to, and once the second party agrees to the location update then it happens. If there are multiple shares it could either be set to occur once >50% click agree, or require the full 100%. I'd also think that the original requester should attach the payment to it when they submit the request that way if whoever has the hotspot wants to move, they can do it as they want, just paying for it.

Depends on where the author wants to go on this HIP but the question is should this "just be fractional rewards earning" or "full ownership including rights to do things like assert, transfer, etc." The former is useful for mining pools and the latter is useful for almost anyone that wants to have fractional ownership on chain.
09:32

09:35

hashc0de 01/05/2021 9:46 AM
I'm not sure why it's irrevocable to be honest. It would make sense that you'd want to redistribute at a later date. The few cases (non exhaustive I'm sure) I can think of are 1. return ownership shares to the other owner. this works easily with two parties if you consider it as a "I revoke my rights" kind of transaction. the chain can just say, cool, i'll redistribute to the other owners. other owners don't need to sign this but probably need to be notified. 2. return ownership shares to the rest of the owners. this works similarly to the #1 since you can also "revoke your rights" and just do it based on the ratio of ownership of other owners. other owners also don't need to sign this. 3. rebalance ownership shares (and optionally add a new owner). this would need all existing owners to sign Potentially you solve the #3 complexity by introducing the concept of needing unanimous or majority consent on ownership changes. Both options could be allowed. (edited)
ðŸŽˆhnt.ChrisV.btcâš¡ 01/05/2021 9:49 AM
or, if you engineer the process as such, it can be agnostic to whether the transferring party is "original" owner or not...it can just be as cut and dry as "how much share of this hotspot do you have? is the amount you're sending less than or equal to that amount? is the target address different than this (origin) address? cool, valid"
09:50
so in other words you can only send less than or up to the amount you hold, and there is really no consideration in the first place who was "original" owner and who is "sub" owner

Anthonyra 01/05/2021 2:15 PM
A little more detail in regards to my earlier message to help answer some of these concerns based on my thoughts. I think that when it comes to ownership (defined as being able to sign for assert locations, transfer, and the like) it should be separated from the intentions of this HIP. For a couple of reasons, if I own 10% of a hotspot I doubt my vote would be worth anything in its actual usage. If I owned >50% I would expect my vote to be the only one. This can be accomplished during this process very easily if separated. If the split creates a majority owner or if ownership is wanted but <50% reward then they can just do a hotspot transfer of ownership and maintain the reward split. This however would allow people to invest in the hopes that the owner doesn't do what is suggested by Chris V. and is unlikely unless you've made some enemies since even though rewards are split both parties have skin in the game. With regards to the reward split I think it can be considered irrevocable I think it makes sense that the rewards can't be reallocated unless all parties currently performing said split signs for the new rewards split making it one and one doesn't seem like a good move forward. (edited)

Greg5 01/08/2021 11:12 AM
This sounds a bit like oil/gas fractional ownership. However, one thing I have not yet become comfortable with on this hip is the fact that hotspot hosts (the actual people) relocate. If I understand correctly, there are likely 3 types of relationships that would use this automatic allocation of earnings. 1) current owner/host relationships, 2) those that truly want to share ownership of a business activity, and 3) service providers that want to provide service in exchange for a portion of the proceeds (during the period the service is provided). The "irrevocable" aspect seems to me to only fit relationship type 2. From my view, it runs against the needs of type 1 and type 3. The big issue with relationship type 1, is that people move. Take a scenario where an ideal host location is on the 3rd story or higher of an urban area. This would tend to be an apartment. In the United States, the average number of moves for a person is 6.4 times between the age of 18 and 45. I would have deep concerns, as a hotspot owner, in granting a host in an apartment an irrevocable share of the revenue stream from a hotspot, knowing that their residency could be "relatively transient" compared to my business goals. In addition, the hotsport owner themselves could move, and could want to relocate all the hotspots to their new city. It seems to me that the assignment of revenue share for relationship type 1 needs to be changeable by the owner at anytime. The same would be true for people in category 3. And, I think that there are more people currently that fit in relationship of type 1 than type 2.
3
11:12
If I were to put on my "software requirements gathering and design" hat, I would add an attribute to specify if the assignment of revenue stream was permanent or not, to allow a way to meet the broadest range of scenarios. If I were to put on my "KISS" hat, and look at the biggest current area of needs as I see them (which could be very different from the area of needs that others are aware of), then II would only implement revocable assignment of revenue stream. The could allow an owner to assign a percentage of revenue to the host, but change it annually when renegotiating the hotspot hosting agreement terms (just like apartment leases are revised and renewed annually), and also change it immediately when the host moves.
11:18
Having been the executor of 2 estates, and been around estate settlement issues of others, I'm also VERY sensitive to how things work out upon the death of someone. In the irrevocable scenario, I can forsee a huge legal nightmare when the host dies, and their irrevocable share becomes part of the deceased host's estate. Most people are not yet sophisticated enough to even think to include digital/virtual asset rights in their estate planning, even if they have the forethought to do estate planning of any kind. In such a scenario, it would cost the original owner too much to deal with the probate court, so the irrevocable share could easily get lost forever.
1
11:21
Also, perhaps I missed it, but what is the overlap of this and being able to transfer a hotspot to a different wallet? (the scenario where the hardware owner chooses to sell the hotspot to someone else). If I'm the legal owner of the hardware (the hotspot), can I bypass the "irrevocable" aspect by simply transferring the hotspot to another wallet that I own?
Greg5 01/08/2021 11:29 AM
If I'm the original hotspot owner, and I'm using this irrevocable feature to give the host their share, then the only way I could see using it is if the hosting agreement becomes written the way that leases are handled for roof-mounted cell towers, for billboard space leases, and roof-top solar panel leases. The new location owner has to accept the associated hotspot lease as part of the transfer of ownership of the real estate. However, that doesn't work in the case of the host being a resident of an apartment. Thoughts? (edited)
11:32
I'm very on board with a modifiable (revocable) assignment of the mined HNT. I definitely see the usefulness of that. I'm just not sure that I see benefits to irrevocable assigment that outweigh the challenges it creates.

@ericmaxwell If I understand the proposed hip correctly, it looks like it is intending to address both true co-ownership situations, as well as owner-host situations. In general, it appears to me to support true co-ownership situations. I listed the one example in an attempt to provide a tangible example rather than only theoretical discussion. From my view, irrevocable makes sense for true co-ownership, but I think it would be in the best interest of owners in the owner-host relationship to avoid using the functionality. @georgica â€” SyncroBit is correct that no one would be forcing me to utilize the ability. Greg5 01/08/2021 4:57 PM
The US tax implications would vary based on circumstances I believe, and may not be trivial to discern. The initial irrevocable assignment might be done as part of an agreement for a hotspot to be hosted. Or, it could have been a sale of a future revenue stream. I suspect those 2 scenarios would be treated differently. Even in the latter scenario, after I googled sale of revenue stream (related to sale of contracts), I found this quote: "it is important to distinguish between proceeds from the present sale of the future right to earn income (capital gain) and the present sale of the future right to earned income (ordinary income)". Steps would need to be taken to determine which portion of proceeds, if any, was a sale of a capital asset, and what portion was ordinary income. If any portion was a capital asset, you'd have to know your basis to determine the gain or loss. I can't remember from my earlier reading if the hip would allow a subsequent transfer (presumably as a sale) from the irrevocable fractional owner to a different owner. If so, those issues would be relevant for each subsequent seller/buyer. Maybe someone that does a deeper dive will discover a simpler answer. I'm simply pointing an initial arrow for someone to do a first look if they want. https://www.taxlawforchb.com/2017/07/sale-of-a-contract-capital-gain-or-ordinary-income/
Lou Vlahos
Sale of A Contract: Capital Gain or Ordinary Income?
Maximize Capital Gain In the sale of a business, it is the goal of every business owner and his tax adviser to minimize the amount of gain recognized and,
17:03
I only provided the above to respond to someone's question. I completely get that any tax considerations are outside of the scope of the hip, and depend on jurisdiction. Each person would clearly be responsible for handling the tax consequences, if any. I also chose to not even look at whether it could be considered a sale of a security.

hashc0de 01/26/2021 2:59 PM
Reviewed your updates. This direction makes sense. Some folks on the team also have been wanting a way for hotspots to split the rewards across multiple accounts for a while so this fits with something we wanted. Open the PR for sure. Some suggestions:
14:59
I think we should focus just on rewards splitting and not on ownership. I think ownership opens up a new can of worms around having to align blockchain rules around local ownership laws and practice. I'd rather keep the blockchain out of it and just let the owner and the owner's wallet be responsible for all changes on a gateway. If, at some point, we implement an on chain multisig of wallets then this could be transitioned to some kind of group ownership model but we'll have to assume that mining pools and hosts will be okay with one owner here. It also simplifies the changes.
5
14:59
I think we should divorce the implementation detail of using transfer_gateway vs some other new type of transaction. In fact, calling a new type of transaction that adjusts rewards_addresses or something like that as a field in the ledger could make sense too.
14:59
I could imagine that rewards_addresses or whatever we want to call it could be map of addresses and splits. You could validate that the ledger will always have those splits add up to 100 and have the minimum split be 1 (for example). The latter could be set as a chain variable.
14:59
We can also have a separate chain variable that limits the number of splits that are allowed. We can do this to reduce the computational complexity of the rewards transaction. Something we probably want to keep an eye on as more gateways that need to be rewarded come online.
rawrmaan 01/26/2021 3:06 PM
^ Love this feedback. That's exactly how I would do it.

ericmaxwell 01/27/2021 10:01 AM
One note I wanted to make regarding the capability to securitize a fleet of hotspots - the use case that I envision is a company like Emrit would sell off a % of a fleet of hotspots in a specific region before theyâ€™re actually deployed. For example, they could sell a bundled 10% stake in 100 hotspots in the greater NY metropolitan area for $50,000. Regions that are already relatively saturated would sell at a discount and regions that are relatively untouched would sell at a premium. Similarly, urban areas would generally sell at a premium and rural areas would sell at a discount. This way, Emrit hedges their deployment risk and investors are able to deploy capital at a larger scale than they would be otherwise

Zwibbledibble42 01/29/2021 2:45 PM
I agree with @hashc0de regarding split return being in the hands of the owner. Especially for those expanding past personal contacts for hosting, the ability to pull reward splits is one of the few real levers you have to ensure host compliance. Yes you can have a contract that lays everything out, but actual enforcement would likely be costly and time consuming. If for whatever reason the owner needs to pull the hotspot, which is their right as the owner, they need the hosts permission to do so. This allows a situation where a stubborn host can abscond with a percentage of hotspot earnings and the owner has no recourse other than legal action. Even if the host were to give the physical hotspot back, if they don't revoke their share, the owner is left with very few options to recover that portion of the hotspot. The irrevocable split provision makes the hotspot owner choose between a heightened risk profile or convenience in rewards payout, which is self defeating as "the sole purpose of the hip is to enable rewards splitting on chain"
5
ML 01/29/2021 2:48 PM

Zwibbledibble42 01/29/2021 2:56 PM
That's my opinion of how it should be, but no in the hip as its currently written

Joey pinned a message to this channel. 02/01/2021 11:44 AM
Zwibbledibble42 02/01/2021 3:55 PM
So I get that you can already keep 100% and then share after the fact, but that complicates things from a tax perspective in addition to making more administrative headache for both the owner and the host. On Chain Rewards Splitting in general is a great workaround here, which is why Iâ€™m 99% on board with this HIP. Owners donâ€™t have to worry about accounting for the tax burden they incur by directly minting the coin across multiple hosts and then sending recurring payments manually. Less manual math done by me, a dumbass, makes the relationship inherently more trustworthy, and hosts donâ€™t need to manually verify their earnings percentages if itâ€™s done automatically on chain, even if Patrium makes it super easy to do these splits and payouts.
15:55
My understanding of the initial motivation is to streamline the owner/host relationship. From the hip: â€œMany of the common workarounds for this problem require more trust, time, energy, technical expertise, or resources than is desirable. The ability to split rewards on-chain would help resolve this issue by eliminating the need for these workarounds in many use cases.â€ Rewards splitting with or without revocable split ameliorates the time, energy, technical and resource costs that currently exist, but trust still needs to be considered in more depth. Revocable and non-revocable splits can both be used to enhance the trust of a relationship, but they function differently based on scale.
15:55
Where the revocable/non revocable split comes in is with regards to incentivizing a streamlined owner/host relationship vs securitization of hotspots. A non-revocable split, as Iâ€™ve previously stated, increases the risk profile of the hotspot owner; an uncooperative host could refuse to return their split, requiring the owner to take a percentage loss in perpetuity or to spend time and likely a sizable amount of money to litigate. Network growth is necessary in the near to medium term for the future success of the network, so anything that incentivizes easy placement of hotspots should be encouraged, ergo streamlining this relationship would have positive benefits to the network. If an appreciable number of owners are unwilling to utilize this new feature then the effectiveness of the hip in terms of growing the network is, at best, neutral.
15:56
In the second portion of the hip regarding securitization however, irrevocable splits do make more sense. For investments on the fleet scale with larger amounts of capital involved, an irrevocable split may be necessary for both parties to come to terms. The argument could be made however that with the greater magnitude of resources involved in such an endeavor, the ability for strong and enforceable contracts to be drawn up would be higher. Legal contracts backed by serious capital could move the burden of trust away from the chain and onto the legal system, making an irrevocable split redundant for large scale enterprises while at best underutilized for smaller time host/owner relationships.
15:56
In summary, there are use cases for both revocable and irrevocable splits, but the benefits of a solely irrevocable split will be outweighed by those of revocable split. Both have a place, and in an ideal world both would be possible, but if weâ€™re only considering one for this HIP, revocable split will be better for the network in the short to medium term.
15:56
The two primary assumptions in this argument are: 1. Fleet securitization agreements will involve enough capital to create sound legal mechanisms to ensure trust, thus making irrevocable split redundant. 2. The average hotspot owner will be uncomfortable using an irrevocable split due to the heightened risk profile, even if the bookkeeping benefits are desirable, at best having no effect on network expansion. This last one is an assumption based on n=1 observations (me), so feel free to shoot me down if Iâ€™m off base here.
15:56
Is the possibility of having both kinds of transactions, revocable and irrevocable, zero? Iâ€™m not great at coding and donâ€™t want to give too much work to the helium team, but it seems like there are arguments for both kinds of splits.

capcom 02/02/2021 11:35 AM
in general our priorities are focused on things that move the needle for either more coverage, or more network utilization. abhay is going to be publishing a roadmap soon, but things that fit the priority list are light gateways, third party integrations, poc/gaming improvements, validators, console features, OSS of console, integration with other lorawan network servers, etc. similar to the comment i left on the on-chain voting HIP, we're not going to always have resources to implement things that don't fit into one of those two buckets (which hopefully everyone agrees are the most important things) and we're going to have to figure out a way for HIP's to be either put in some kind of "pending" state, or for the code itself to be the HIP (ala. Bitcoin/Ethereum)

vihu 02/06/2021 4:03 PM
core#729 looks very promising, thank you for taking the initiative @ericmaxwell A few things: - I'm pretty sure that you can do a similar testing strategy as done in blockchain_payment_v2_SUITE, it works largely independent of the chain and just checks the txn validation constraints - Don't have two versions of rewards_map (one as a list, other as a map) unless there's an absolutely necessary reason for it - What happens when there are two competing reward_split transactions? How do we ensure that only one split transaction for a particular account is valid at a given point in time? Should this be tied to the nonce of an account (I'm leaning towards yes)? Presumably your payments would get messed up if there's also debit happening from the same account using the reward_split txn. - When its time, we'll probably need to run an end-to-end test on the miner side (there's a payment_v2_SUITE in miner as well for reference) - Ensure that you're able to sync the chain with this code running (without the vars activated of course)
ericmaxwell 02/06/2021 4:09 PM
No problem, thank you both for the help. Some of these points listed clear up a few of the questions I have so thank you for that, also I'll try to address the issues brought up here as soon as I can. Do either of you have any sort of documentation / walkthrough I could follow to get the testing suite up and running when the time comes? Or is it relatively straightforward?
vihu 02/06/2021 4:13 PM
I could follow to get the testing suite up and running when the time comes? Or is it relatively straightforward?
It should be relatively straightforward once you get a hang of the test_setup (we have tons of helper functions in blockchain_ct_utils.erl we use all over the place, txn_payment_v2_SUITE is your friend). I can certainly help with testing stuff once we get there
ericmaxwell 02/06/2021 4:14 PM

vihu 02/06/2021 4:14 PM

Ross 02/09/2021 5:04 PM
I've kept quiet because @ericmaxwell knows my position, and also because I myself recognize the perceived bias since I run Patrium. But just to get my view out in the open: I have as much or more interest as a hotspot operator than I do as the operator of Patrium... at least I make more money from hotspots than patrium. I am also interested in this from the perspective of being an attorney. What happens when someone won't relinguish their "entitlement" to earnings? Take them to court? What's a court going to do? Grant an injunction or order specific performance for the blockchain to change the variables? Who has the technology/authority to even do that? What happens then the host loses their wallet because they're a host and not as sophisticated as an owner? I don't disagree that this would make things easier, I just question whether this is wise. With all the problems this can cause, when there are third party solutions such as mylar, sitebot, hotspotty, patrium, etc., it seems like the KISS philosophy might be the best course of action here. I'm not intending to argue the merits in a point/counterpoint, but I wanted to get my view known. In case it wasn't clear, I do not think this is in the best interests of the network for all the above reasons. Let the 3rd parties take on that risk, as they are already providing the services. Even if I didn't run Patrium, I would still feel this way, fwiw.

qwick745 02/09/2021 6:03 PM
While vaguely related - a question I proposed a while ago I believe in HIP19, is what recourse a hotspot owner would have in case of a lost wallet of theirs, or more possibly of a split host like this. If the owner can recall the share and send to a new wallet, either on chain or off chain, hey problem solved with the host losing their wallet. But will there be any way to swap out a security chip to make the hotspot essentially a "new" one if the owner loses their key, or this is an irrevocable split? If that wallet is lost, does the hotspot essentially become a paperweight as it more or less bricked either completely for an owner or some portion for an irrevocable share? I would hope that manufacturers offer a service where hotspots could be returned to them and for $50 or something they could have a new security chip installed. If the owner at least has the ability to recall their share, or everything is shared off chain - I think there will be far fewer occurrences of this. But I do think hosts will lose wallets left and right, making more and more HNT disappear, and possibly hardware go to waste.

hashc0de 02/12/2021 1:19 PM
My advice on this would be to aim to ship the simplest possible change that would be most palatable for the community and for code review. roughly speaking: - owner wallet controlled reward split transaction - transaction generates or updates a reward map to a number of reward recipients - reward map has reward recipients (defaults to owner @ 100%). granularity should be simple integers (1-100). must add up to 100 - maximum number of recipients controlled by a chain var (set value to, say, 3 to start) Subsequent reward split transaction only need to be signed by the owner so we don't have to get signatures from old recipients and potentially new ones. Introducing multisig here is really complicated from a UX perspective.
1
1

HIP24: Reward Splitting · Issue #105 · helium/HIP
Author(s): @ericmheilman Initial PR: #104 Start Date: 2020-12-26 Category: Technical Rendered view: https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/master/0024-reward-splitting.md Summary: This proposal introdu...

jamiedubs 04/08/2021 8:57 AM
@Discodave95 @daniellundgren please note this proposal is for a truly irrevocable transfer of reward %, and would not be suitable for common hotspot hosting setups. Those can be managed through one of the many community apps for that purpose, like Hotspotty or Patrium. The rationale for this is discussed in the HIP and above. To re-iterate: Anything added to the blockchain causes bloat and blockchain bloat is a serious long-term concern Any changes to blockchain logic are serious and heavily reviewed. Thus any "on-chain host management" would be severely limited, and receive slow and infrequent updates. Ideally it would never be updated. Revocable payments to hosts can and are curerntly being managed off-chain. Additionally, because these are centralized web applications, the business logic can be easily upgraded and new features added. Other currencies, fancy referral stuff, whatever. By contrast, trustlessly transferring an irrevocable % of rewards is not possible off-chain. This feature would enable unique opportunities for securitizing rewards and financing hotspot deployment operations. In summary if you were to use this feature, you could not take that % of rewards back. The recipient would need to voluntarily transfer it back to you. If that point is not abundantly clear, this feature might be too dangerous to be rolled out. There's no undo.

krby 04/11/2021 10:41 AM
Just a note about tax implications: IANACPA and IANAL so this is just me passing on advice I was given by a tax advisor who felt to me like he was knowledgable about crypto. The responsibility is yours. For my hosted hotspots, the advice was given (assuming I'm not filing this as a business entity and this is in the US) was this: Pay the host in HNT. Treat the hotspot as if both me and the host earned daily. If I wanted to, I could split each reward transaction, but the advice was that I should be fine rolling up rewards daily but not a longer period (like weekly). So for a 70/30 split. I report mining 70% of the rewards each day and the host reports 30% of the rewards. This only works if I'm transfering HNT to the host and not paying in USD. I don't have to pay the HNT daily, I can hold it (he called it holding for the benefit of the host), and pay out monthly or quarterly or something else.

krby 04/14/2021 7:43 PM
The IRS considers cryptocurrency a security (like a stock) and mining coins is like your employer giving you shares of stock. That value at the time you mine it is reported as income and then that value is the cost basis when you sell it later.

vihu 04/22/2021 5:24 PM
From Rationale and Alternatives:
Enable trust-minimized reward splitting of hotspots
If an owner "A" is splitting rewards with actors [B, C, D]; wouldn't B, C, D have to have trust in A? Or do we have some sort of a binding agreement on chain? That seems like a different can of worms altogether? What happens when A doesn't honor this and so on...
Reduce the time, energy, technical expertise and resources necessary to maintain host-owner relationships
I believe this to be a false assumption. If we have to establish trust among host-owner relationships, that's not an insignificant amount of time, work whether it's on-chain or off-chain.
Enable the securitization of hotspots
Sorry, I don't understand how this enables security of hotspots? Anyone can have multiple identities on chain and pretend to split rewards if they want to within an all-virtual network. What kind of security are we talking here?
Remove DC cost associated with owners regularly paying out HNT to hosts
The transaction itself would also have atleast some amount of fee too I'd imagine
Simplify tax reporting

Helios49r 04/23/2021 9:52 PM
Itâ€™s worth pointing out that transferring HNT from a wallet owned by one person to a wallet owned by another person is a qualifying event for tax purposes. The IRS views crypto as property, so making that transfer is like selling property and will trigger capital gains taxes if there has been a change in the price of HNT between when it was mined and when it was transferred. I am not a CPA, but thatâ€™s what I was told by two separate CPAs, one of whom was also a Tax Atty with a specialization in crypto. That is part of the reason I am so interested in this HIP. It would solve the tax issue for owners, hosts, and referrers, which canâ€™t be solved off chain w/o doing daily transfers and having to pay the transfer fee for the transfer to each recipient.

it's not "pretty simple". Introducing rewards splitting on chain complicates a lot of the existing ledger code and adds more complexity to the existing (already complex) rewards generation logic. as you probably have all seen, generating this block takes the longest and the CG has to agree on this. there's likely a path to this with separating out the ownership wallet from the rewards wallet and some answers to questions around ownership with multisig keys. we talked a little bit about this on the core team over the week and owe the community some notes (probably not for another month until after validators are launched) on what we think the path may be here.

krby 06/04/2021 9:14 AM
This is not the same across the globe. "Owning a business" has some specific legal and tax meanings in various places. In many countries/states/regions, an individual is allowed to do something for profit and declare the income, but is not required to declare themselves a business. There may be advantages to doing so, but it isn't required in all places. You do have to declare the income for tax purposes in most/all regions, no matter what. (edited)
krby

In many countries/states/regions, an individual is allowed to do something for profit and declare the income, but is not required to declare themselves a business. There may be advantages to doing so, but it isn't required in all places. You do have to declare the income for tax purposes in most/all regions, no matter what. (edited)
Pappus 06/04/2021 9:16 AM

09:17

krby 06/04/2021 9:19 AM
Sure. In the United States: * I can mine cryptocurrency. I have to declare it as income on my personal tax returns. I am not required to setup a business entity like an LLC or C-Corp. So legally, I am earning this income not some other entity. If I want, I can setup a LLC and have that entity own and operate the miners. If I do, I have more overhead for tax prep and bookkeeping and other expenses, but I can also take advantage of some legal protections and writing off expenses that I cannot do as an individual. (edited)

Jackisch 06/07/2021 7:36 AM
I think you might be confusing tax evasion with tax avoidance. The former is terribly illegal. The latter is intelligently following the rules as they are laid out to minimize tax bills, but still paying what is rightfully owed to the government. HIP 24 seems to benefit specific countries, with no real impact on others. For example, in the US, having this built on chain would actually stabilize tax risks and reduce liability for things that, imo, shouldn't be placed on the shoulders of those pushing the network forward through deployment. I also have concerns that forcing this to be an off chain solution carries security risks that could be a massive problem for those using 3rd-party applications to manage distribution of rewards. (edited)
Jackisch

Jackisch 06/07/2021 7:44 AM
Ah, I see. The way I read the above conversation, it seemed to me that people are advocating for HIP 24 because of the relief it provides to ethical operators who want to pay their fair share in taxes without incurring additional, needless liability. I'm in favor, and this is my argument for it as well. I've seen too many off-chain solutions end with massive security breaches. I understand that one argument against hip 24 is that it complicates the blockchain. I think incurring that cost on the blockchain is better than putting the burden off-chain. The whole point of decentralization is to create as trustless of an environment as possible. But forcing it off-chain just shifts the trust on to 3rd parties who could potentially sneak code into their solutions to act maliciously.

Jackisch 06/08/2021 7:28 PM

hashc0de 06/08/2021 7:38 PM
So Tushar's recommendation was a contract on the Solana chain. This could probably be generalized to work on other chains like ETH or Cosmos as well. In theory what you'd need is a couple of pieces. 1. A bridge between Helium and the other chain. On the Helium side, you'd have to be able to understand the other chain's addresses and write that to the ledger. You'd essentially "mint HNT" to that address which can only be unlocked by that private key that's compatible with another chain's private key. 2. You'd need an actor that can go on both chains. It has the private key for both sides. 3. It needs to issue a bridge or burn transaction: to make it "consumed" on the native Helium side. 4. It needs to mint the HNT or equivalent on the other chain, atomically. 5. It needs to do the splits based on whatever the program is configured to do. Btw. This is super rough and probably missing a few important pieces. Steps 1-4 are probably all useful outside of this particular HIP 24 proposal. The hardest parts are around how do you create a trustless bridge. Solana has already solved this with the Wormhole project. It requires a certain cryptography upgrades that we now support with HIP 29 and 30. There are also staked and not fully decentralized versions of steps 1-4 like ThorChain. (edited)

Which is a reasonable position but I'm not sure one is better than the other.

SCK Jr 06/19/2021 4:31 PM
I am no expert with regard to helium or hip24, but I have managed a handful of businesses and am well versed in tax codes for the US as I have been preparing Schedule C and 1120 forms for sole proprietors and Corporations for 30 years. The majority of the conversation here with regard to hobby is based on incorrect assumptions. The hobby designations used to be loopholes for deducting money that you spent on folly and fun even if you could not earn any profit, thus it was a way that an average w-2 (wage earner) could legally write off some expenses and lower his/her tax liability just like a "real" business might. There were always strict limits on "losses" and if you ever actually earned income it was and still is taxable. There was NEVER any loophole that allowed a hobby to earn a profit after expenses that was somehow not considered income and therefore taxable. Interestingly as of 2018, you can no longer even write off hobby expenses - essentially the IRS is forcing you to use at least a Schedule C to itemized deductions if you so choose to take them. The bottom line is any net income is taxable once it is more than your minimum taxable amount. You can call it anything you like, it can be declared in any form you like, but it is taxable. Any net income earned from Helium mining beyond your deductible expenses and in excess of your minimum taxable income is taxable and failure to declare and pay is evasion.

SCK Jr 06/27/2021 8:26 AM
By the time that the IRS is forcibly doing anything you have already lost. There are definitely scales of taxability within and from private vs business, but as they say, I am not giving tax advise as every case is unique. That said, in the US there are many small business that are really nothing more that people working for yourself, meaning instead of getting a job with a company a person elects to "hustle" money by providing a service or a shop, etc. This is a Schedule C business by IRS definition. There is no created business entity such as a tradition corporation and legally speaking the person is conducting business in their own name. In my opinion, based on conversation within this thread, this is the category that most here will fall under - loosely formed business or side hustles. Within this scope there is no real distinction or scale as per the IRS. The schedule C is filed with your personal return and any net income is taxed at your personal rate. This income would be taxed same as any "personal" misc. income that was claimed on the return. Regardless of classification, the net result is the same and will be taxable.

Broadcast 07/23/2021 11:29 PM
I posted this elsewhere and was pointed to this HIP. I would love to see this implemented -> I have something that I would like to propose. A mechanism on the blockchain to execute the sharing of earnings. Essentially what I am thinking is the ability to allow an owner to divert a percentage of HNT earnings to a host's wallet seamlessly. They can initiate the contract, input a % and end the contract all from the app. An owner would ask a host to download the app, and send the wallet address. Then the owner could select which hotspot they want the contract executed on, paste the host's wallet address in and enter a % to send on a particular day each month. I don't know how intensive it would be to incorporate this but I can see a lot of different use cases. Owners could manage their own host agreements, they could use it as a mechanism to send family HNT at regular monthly intervals, they could use it to send a % to an exchange address at regular intervals - I think the use case goes on and on, and the idea has a lot of merit.
3
Broadcast 07/23/2021 11:38 PM
I just reviewed HIP24 in it's entirety. I agree with everything written in the HIP and it fits perfectly with my vision of reward splitting, except for Reward Split Revocation. The fact that it requires multiple parties to revoke the split does interfere with some of my perceived use cases. If somebody misplaced their 12 word phrase and locked themselves out of their wallet, the owner would forever lose the split.
23:39
In the case of owners and hosts, if an owner revokes a split, the host should receive a notification on the Helium App that reward splitting has been revoked. They then have the power to take the hotspot offline.
Broadcast 07/23/2021 11:54 PM
As an owner you should not have to relinquish control of your device, outside of physically accessing it. However, HIP24 is expansive beyond the Owner/Host relationship. We are talking about cryptocurrency here, and so efforts to make transactions/splitting trustless are prudent, but there should be some control retained by the owner. Perhaps a two-part transaction takes place when ceasing reward sharing. If an owner initiates a stop on a contract the HNT split going forward is held in a separate "locked" wallet until the other party authorizes the Stop. The other party would have some form of time limit to Accept or Reject the Contract Stop. If the stop is neither Accepted or Rejected by the other party before timing out, the funds are released to the owner. If the other party Accepts the contract stop, the funds earned after the Stop was initiated are "unlocked" and transferred to the Owner's main wallet.
23:56
I'm still caught up on how a secondary party could reject the stop in a way that could protect them, ensuring the initial contract is upheld.
Broadcast 07/24/2021 12:14 AM
Maybe the implementation of Contract Stop Rejection Passphrase would help to solve this? If the other party rejects the stop a passphrase is generated and provided to the receiver of the split. If the owner executes a Contract Stop and the other party rejects the Contract Stop, then the Owner is required to enter the generated passphrase. This could allow for negotiation between the parties in the event of a dispute on contract terms. This stops the payment that the other party would normally receive and does not allow either party to access the HNT earned Post-Contract Stop. This implementation would allow an owner to revoke the split, but forces both parties to accept the Contract Stop. Should both parties accept the contract stop, then any HNT earned after the stop is initiated is unlocked and sent to the owner's main wallet. If the contract stop is rejected by the other party the only way for the owner to unlock the funds after the lock is with the other party's passphrase. If the passphrase is not entered within the time limit then the locked wallet HNT is distributed to both parties equally and the Contract Stop executes. (edited)
Broadcast 07/24/2021 12:23 AM
This is not entirely ideal for the other party, but there is a forced compromise by both parties. The owner only receives half of the locked HNT balance. Note - this balance is only comprised of the split % initiated in the original reward split laid out by the Owner and can only accrue in the locked wallet from the moment the Contract Stop is called. If both parties stalemate, and do not reach resolution, the other party still receives some earnings from after the Contract Stop is initiated, but ultimately the Owner is able to regain control and ends the split.
Dr. J 07/26/2021 7:21 PM
I believe that HIP 24 should be passed and that the splitting needs to be on chain due to FinCEN laws regarding Money Service Businesses. Hosting services such as Fairspot and the one that we run are integral pieces to the development of the network and deploying of mass amounts of hotspots. We are a "small fish" and plan to install 1000 hotspots by end of 2022. We are installing these almost exclusively in towns & cities that have either zero or very few current hotspots. We are currently unable to pay out in cryptocurrency due to FinCEN laws on MSBs, because in the eyes of regulators we are an MSB. @rawrmaan may care to chime in, but we were explicitly directed to not payout in HNT by our lawyer who specializes in cryptocurrency & blockchain businesses.

rawrmaan 07/26/2021 7:24 PM
That's a strange take on the role of a hotspot hosting service. I don't see why that would be true. I certainly haven't been alerted to any MSB issues and my accountants and lawyers are fairly crypto-literate.
19:25
We're just paying independent contractors. Doesn't matter if it's cash, HNT or Visa gift cards as far as I understand.
Dr. J 07/26/2021 7:25 PM
https://kelman.law/insights/money-transmitter-licensing-for-u-s-crypto-companies/
Money Transmitter Licensing for U.S. Crypto Companies | Kelman Law
As a crypto-dealing U.S. business, you need "money service business" and "money transmitter" registration and licensing . Here's how to avoid FinCEN's wrath.
Dr. J
https://kelman.law/insights/money-transmitter-licensing-for-u-s-crypto-companies/
rawrmaan 07/26/2021 7:30 PM
This meant that companies who accepted virtual currency from one party to another party and vice versa, or exchange fiat currency for any digital currency, or even just accepted crypto from customers on behalf of a merchant, were considered money transmitters. However, individuals and businesses who simply exchanged cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin for products and services, and vice versa, were not.
We are the latter. We're simply exchanging HNT for the service of placing the hotspot at our host's location. So I think this article pretty clearly confirms that we are not money transmitters.
2
Dr. J 07/26/2021 8:23 PM
I am not here to argue the law as I am not a lawyer. My job is not to interpret the law, that's why we hire lawyers, to provide direction and keep us out of legal trouble. My point is that our legal counsel, who has many large crypto mining clients spanning multiple different cryptocurrencies, advised us to not pay directly in HNT. In his opinion, we would be in violation of FinCEN laws and be required to register as an MSB and complete AML/KYC registration. The penalties for failure to register as an MSB are steep, and it opens us and all other hosting companies up to a tremendous amount of legal complications that are completely avoidable if HIP - 24 were to be passed. I will reach out to our lawyer to see if he can write something up for me to post to this HIP channel. If you operate a Helium hosting company, I encourage you to reach out to a lawyer that specializes in cryptocurrency mining and get their opinion. I was very disappointed to hear that we should not pay in HNT, as this would have been an extremely easy process to code & automate. The burden of compliance with MSB, KYC, and AML registration as well risk of legal trouble for violation of federal law if we choose not to are very strong arguments in favor of passing HIP - 24. By splitting rewards we would be able to avoid ever touching the token, pay our hosts in HNT, and continue to build the network.

This part of U.S. law is confusing for Europeans. In the Netherlands we do not have capital gains tax. In most cases gains from trades add to capital and are taxed under general capital tax (ranging from 0.59 % tot maximal 1.76%). Capital tax is based on the capital a private person has per Janurary 1 of the fiscal year. For businesses or private persons that have business activity it adds to general income tax in most cases.

wolas 12/19/2021 3:54 PM
1. Smart contracts don't sit between the blockchain and mining payouts, if anything they're run after.
How can smart contracts run after the block is mined? They run before in the EVM (eth) and the resulting state change is appended to the blockchain. I think you're mixing up mining as proof of work/proof of stake (settlement - validators in helium) with proof of coverage in helium (which is actually state). So 'mining payouts' you're referring to are validators' rewards for appending new block to the blockchain and not proof of coverage rewards which this HIP is about. So yes, this would possible to implement on the blockchain layer as a different type of transaction
2. The community already does (Hotspotty) and we have means to provide community-supported tooling for just this sort of thing
a) Hotspotty is not an open source tool, it can be made as paid feature anytime b) Hotspotty allows you to track your payments to hosts but it does not make the payments for you c) how to you know their ETL is updated and on track with all transactions included? Additional layer of trust - this is something that should be avoided in my opinion, it it was settled on the blockchain there would be no dispute about the payments
Why would this be any better than a community-supported tool that allows you to easily manage payment splits?
I just gave you three reasons above, please refer to them
But... do we really want a world where someone with means can slap a "tax" on tens of thousands of devices? sounds bad...
No one said it does have to work like that
